content.text: (a) Determine the speed of the ball at time \(= 1.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
(b) Describe the speed of the ball between time \(= 2.0 \mathrm{~s}\) and time \(= 5.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
(c) Calculate the distance moved by the ball between time \(= 2.0 \mathrm{~s}\) and time \(= 5.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
distance = m
(d) Fig. 1.2 shows the two vertical forces acting on the ball at time \(=3.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
Give the term used to describe each force
upward force X is
downward force Y is
1 Fig. 1.1 shows the speed-time graph for a ball falling through the air
2 (a) A student determines the density of a liquid, by using the equipment shown in Fig. 2.1
Describe how the student uses the equipment to determine the density of the liquid
(b) Fig. 2.2 shows a metal block
The density of the metal is \(8.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\)
Calculate the mass of the metal block
(a) Explain why the solid cone in Fig. 3.1 is more stable than the solid cuboid
(b) The weight of the solid cuboid is 48 N . The area of the solid cuboid in contact with the ground is 32 cm2
Calculate the pressure exerted by the solid cuboid on the ground
pressure on ground = N/cm2
(c) A horizontal force of 15 N tilts the solid cone, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Calculate the moment of the 15 N force about the pivot
moment = NÂ·cm

3 Fig. 3.1 shows a cross-section through the centre of a solid cone and a cross-section through the centre of a solid cuboid. The cone and the cuboid are placed on the ground as shown in Fig. 3.1. The solid cone is more stable than the solid cuboid
The symbol \(\times\) indicates the position of the centre of gravity of each object
(a) Describe how the power station generates electrical power from the chemical energy stored in biofuels
(b) State one advantage and one disadvantage, apart from cost, of generating electrical power using biofuels compared with generating electrical power using fossil fuels
advantage
disadvantage
4 A power station uses biofuels to generate electrical power
(a) After lifting the load, the motor is switched off. Fig. 5.2 represents the transfer of energy from the battery to the load in Fig. 5.1
In Fig. 5.2, add the names of the energy stores
(b) The weight of the load is 8.0 N . The motor lifts the load through a vertical distance of 0.60 m
Calculate the work done on the load
work done on load = J
(c) The current in the motor is 0.40 A . The potential difference across the motor is 6.0 V
Calculate the power of the electric motor
power of electric motor = W
5 An electric motor lifts a load, as shown in Fig. 5.1
(a) Describe the arrangement, separation and motion of the particles in liquid water
(b) State how thermal energy moves through the metal container from the heater to the water
(c) Describe how thermal energy spreads throughout the water
(d) The water is heated until it is boiling. The air pressure in the room is standard atmospheric pressure
State the temperature at which the water boils
temperature = \(^{\circ}C\)
6 A student warms some water in a metal container using an electric heater, as shown in Fig. 6.1
7 (a) Fig. 7.1 represents a ray of red light entering one side of a glass block
On Fig. 7.1 draw the path of the ray of red light through the glass block and into the air
(b) Fig. 7.2 represents the dispersion of white light by a glass prism
Two of the colours of the visible spectrum are shown in Fig. 7.2
State the other five colours of the visible spectrum in the correct order
(i) In Fig. 7.3, one region is unlabelled
State the name of the unlabelled region
(ii) Describe one use of gamma rays
(iii) Describe one harmful effect on people of excessive exposure to gamma rays
red
violet
(c) Fig. 7.3 represents the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
(a) Describe how the tuning fork produces sound
(b) State the normal frequency range of sounds that humans can hear. Give the unit
from to
(c) Two students determine a value for the speed of sound in air. Fig. 8.2 illustrates the method they use

The girl starts the stopwatch when she sees the metal plates clash together. She stops the stopwatch when she hears the sound of the clashing metal plates. The students use the time on the stopwatch to calculate the speed of sound
The value for the speed of sound obtained by the students is different from the true value for the speed of sound in air
Explain why the students' value is different
8 A student strikes a tuning fork on a wooden block. The tuning fork is held close to the students' ear as shown in Fig. 8.1
(a) Fig. 9.2 shows part of the circuit diagram for the circuit in Fig. 9.1
Complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 9.2 to represent the circuit in Fig. 9.1. Use standard circuit symbols
(b) The potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp is 11 V and the current in the lamp is 0.44 A
Calculate the resistance of the lamp
resistance = \(\Omega\)
(c) The student moves the sliding contact from position A to position B , as shown in Fig. 9.3
State and explain any effect on the current in the circuit when the sliding contact is moved from position A to position B
[Total: 9]
9 A student set up the electrical circuit that is shown in Fig. 9.1
(a) Describe how the student uses the apparatus to demonstrate electromagnetic induction
(b) State two separate changes the student must make to the apparatus to increase the electromotive force (e.m.f.) induced in the coil
(i) State a suitable material for the transformer core
(ii) State the term used to describe coil X in Fig. 10.2
(iii) State the term used to describe the type of transformer represented in Fig. 10.2
(c) Fig. 10.2 represents a transformer
10 Fig. 10.1 shows the apparatus used by a student to demonstrate electromagnetic induction
11 (a) Table 11.1 gives information about the particles in an atom

table.html:
name of particlerelative chargelocation in the atom
proton+1in the nucleus
neutron
electronorbiting the nucleus

content.text: Complete the table by writing the correct information in the three empty spaces
(b) State the relative charge on an alpha particle
(c) Compare the penetrating abilities of alpha particles, beta particles and gamma rays
(a) State the term used to describe the force that keeps the Earth in orbit around the Sun
(b) Explain why the Earth has an annual cycle of seasons
(c) The distance of the Earth from the Sun is \(1.48 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\). The speed of light is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the time it takes light from the Sun to reach the Earth
time taken to reach Earth = s
12 Fig. 12.1 represents the Earth's orbit of the Sun
